channel.title: Well this is getting gay, n e one help?
channel.description:
OK 3 days ago well my computer did.. well something i don't know (picture below) and it was completely random now every time i turn on my computer it flashed then my computer restarts, nothing work (safe mode and stuff) for some reason it let me on last night the it started being gay again then again tonight it let me on, i re-installed windows, i thing lol..
Here's the error thing that came up
[img]http://img72.imageshack.us/img72/2273/p1010009od4.jpg[/img] [code]http://img72.imageshack.us/img72/2273/p1010009od4.jpg[/code]
i have to go, so if u cant read, i will type the text later but i have to go atm

Yes, the 99.99999% figure came from my ass. I seem to be wrong though, I couldn’t see bad ram getting far enough to cause a pagefault without causing some other kind of error first, but apparently it happens quite often. Bad mopman.

Lol Mopman … Could Be Harddrive Could Be Ram , Id Ask My Dad , If He Was Still Alive…
[/quote]

Explain how it could be harddrive?[/quote]
The pagefile is stored on the harddrive.

item.source: Well this is getting gay, n e one help?

item.title: Well this is getting gay, n e one help?
item.dc:creator: @MybJames MybJames
item.description:
@MybJames wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:7, topic:71834”]Woot, nobody has a clue what they are giving advice on, as usual.

This message is caused by a bad driver, 99.99999% of the time. (In fact, I don’t know of a single other scenario that can cause this, but I’m sure somebody could come up with one if they tried hard enough.) This could be a recent bit of hardware you bought being made in Eastern China for 2 cents an hour, or even something like a rootkit (they tend to live in kernel-space, too). Try to boot into safemode, if not, re-install.

EDIT: Actually, I amend “I don’t know a single other scenario” - Deadbirds suggestion is worth a try, and I guess your ram COULD have died, although I can’t see that causing this, it would break something else much earlier I’d image.[/quote]

Where did you pull those figures, from your ass?

Faulty ram is a common problem, manufacturers may have not held the ram on either ends, which causes problems. I suggest running memtest86, which is a little program that you burn to a cd, plug into your pc and restart

Leave it running, and when it is finished, report here and tell me how many errors there were (if any)

But yes, Mopman is probably correct, faulty device driver.

Read full topic
item.source: Well this is getting gay, n e one help?

item.title: Well this is getting gay, n e one help?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Woot, nobody has a clue what they are giving advice on, as usual.

This message is caused by a bad driver, 99.99999% of the time. (In fact, I don’t know of a single other scenario that can cause this, but I’m sure somebody could come up with one if they tried hard enough.) This could be a recent bit of hardware you bought being made in Eastern China for 2 cents an hour, or even something like a rootkit (they tend to live in kernel-space, too). Try to boot into safemode, if not, re-install.

EDIT: Actually, I amend “I don’t know a single other scenario” - Deadbirds suggestion is worth a try, and I guess your ram COULD have died, although I can’t see that causing this, it would break something else much earlier I’d image.

Read full topic
